abstracts.cdata!:
Overall, project outcomes are rated
            satisfactory, and sustainability is likely. Lessons
            reinforce the success of close working relationships among
            counterparts, beneficial in terms of additional financial
            resources, and of exposure to other technical, and
            managerial methods. But regardless of success, lessons also
            suggest best practices in road administration, namely, that
            economic analysis should identify optimal choices in the
            selection of road sections, and in the type of pavements to
            be improved, using adequate computer programs in resource
            planning. Furthermore, contractor competitiveness improves
            efficiency, particularly for periodic road maintenance,
            provided adequate supervision of the contractor performance
            is implemented, and that payments are tied to the
            fulfillment of quality requirements. Although the Lithuanian
            Road Fund created the incentive for political
            representatives to support it, questions have been raised as
            to its validity, and whether regular budgetary procedures
            should not replace it, since resources available through the
            Fund are not sufficient to cover maintenance of the national
            road network. Co-financing is of limited value for projects
            with incremental work programs, as in this case, though it
            is worth considering in projects with a single large
            component, to reduce costs.

abstracts.cdata!:
The overall objectives of the Highway
            Project are to assist the Government of Lithuania in
            preserving its road network, and to improve the efficiency
            of Lithuania's road maintenance operations. The
            specific objectives of the project are: a) to expand the
            level quality and efficiency of periodic maintenance for
            roads and bridge repairs; b) to reduce vehicle operating
            costs and improve the environment by completing bypasses,
            and to help preserve the urban infrastructure by financing
            an expanded program of street improvements and maintenance
            for the cities of Vilnius and Kaunas; c) to facilitate road
            financing by encouraging road user charge system; d) to
            encourage and support the development of private road
            construction and engineering industries; and e) to improve
            road safety. The components are in three areas. The
            Lithuanian Road Administration includes: a) repaving of
            portions of the Regional Road Network; b) completion of
            partially constructed by-passes; c) bridge repairs; d) a
            road safety program; and e) technical services. In the
            municipality of Vilnius the components are the repaving and
            reconstruction of high priority streets and bridge repairs
            as well as technical support. In the municipality of Kaunas
            the components are the repaving and upgrading of streets and
            technical support.
